name: Anissa Abi-Dargham
biography: Anissa Abi-Dargham is an expert in areas of molecular imaging, pharmacology, schizophrenia and addiction. Dr. Abi-Dargham employs the use of Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging to study the neurobiology of schizophrenia and mental illnesses. Her research has resulted in seminal findings describing the complex alterations of dopamine transmission in schizophrenia and their relationship to clinical symptoms, cognition and response to treatment. She is a member of the National Academy of Medicine.  Read bio

name: James Bernasko
department: Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Endocrinology
title_1: Obstetrician-Gynecologist; Director, Regional Perinatal Center; Director, Stony Brook Prenatal Diagnosis and Therapy Center; Clinical Associate Professor, Maternal-Fetal Medicine
biography: Dr. Bernasko’s specialties are high-risk pregnancies, diabetes in pregnancy, multiple pregnancies, preterm birth, and medical complications in pregnancy.

name: Thomas V. Bilfinger
title_1: Thoracic Surgeon, Professor of Surgery Director, Thoracic Surgery, Co-Director, Aortic Center, Team Leader and Co-Director, Lung Cancer Evaluation Center
biography: Thomas Bilfinger’s practice encompasses both heart and lung surgery. He provides consultation and surgical care for adult patients with advanced forms of heart disease, and also for adults with a range of benign and malignant pulmonary diseases. His practice involves new, minimally invasive procedures, including thoracic aortic stenting for aneurysms and radiofrequency, and cryoablation for lung tumors.

name: Michael Bender
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Michael Bender’s research interests span the areas of data structures and algorithms, I/O-efficient computing, scheduling, databases, and parallel computing. He was Founder and Chief Scientist at an enterprise database company (Tokutek) which was acquired in 2015.

name: Christy Beneri
title_1: Assistant Professor; Fellowship Director, Pediatric Infectious Diseases
biography: Christy Beneri specializes in pediatric lyme and tick-borne illnesses, tuberculosis, vaccine development and pediatric transplant. Her research interests include antimicrobial stewardship and standardized protocol development.

name: Julia Bear
biography: Julia Bear's research focuses on the influence of gender on negotiation outcomes, as well as conflict management and work-life issues in organizations.  In her research, she investigates what factors influence the gender gap typically seen in negotiation outcomes, and how an understanding of these factors can help to reduce the gender gaps seen in organizations.    Read bio

name: Matthew Barish
title_1: Radiologist, Vice-Chair of Radiology Informatics, Associate Professor of Radiology, Division Co-Chief of Abdominal Imaging, Director of Magnetic Resonance Imaging
biography: Matthew Barish’s areas of major research include virtual colonoscopy, 3D imaging, tumor metric core, MR imaging of the bile ducts, MR cholangiopancreatography of the biliary ducts, MR of the pancreatic duct and abdominal imaging, predictors of prostate carcinoma, accuracy of gray-scale and color doppler US and serum markers. His clinical responsibilities include interpretation of plain films, fluoroscopy, computer tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET/CT), virtual colonoscopy, ultrasound (US), and emergency radiology.

name: Ahmed Belazi
title_1: Director of Planning and Staff Development
biography: Ahmed Belazi advises the Vice President for Student Affairs on strategy and long-term planning and leads the Division of Student Affairs' assessment activities fostering a culture of evidence in practice. Additionally, he provides vision, design, and coordination towards the enhancement of the workforce productivity, improvement of staff morale, and professional development.

name: Marina D Azzimonti Renzo
biography: Marina Azzimonti is an expert in measuring the effects of the increasing partisan conflict in on the U.S. economy. Research she conducted shows this increased partisan conflict discourages investments by households and firms. Based on this research, she developed the “Partisan Conflict Index,” which tracks the degree of political disagreement among U.S. politicians, and is now issued monthly by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve.

name: Michelle S Ballan
biography: Michelle Ballan’s practice and research aims to ameliorate barriers impacting services and treatment for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Her scholarly work addresses two main foci for women with disabilities: intimate partner violence and reproductive justice.  She is a mentor for human rights disability advocates and her international disability work is in Vietnam. In 2015, she received the Mid-Career Exemplary Social Work Leader Award from the National Association of Social Workers, New York City Chapter.   Read bio

name: Michael Barnhart
biography: Michael Barnhart is an expert in  history of American foreign relations and politics, AmericanEast Asian relations, and modern Japanese history.  His works include  Japan Prepares for Total War ,  Japan and the World Since 1868 , and numerous articles, book chapters and book reviews. He is currently working on a two-volume survey of a political history of American foreign policy tentatively titled,  E Pluribus . Read bio

name: Saïd Amir Arjomand
department: Sociology, Director of the Institute for Global Studies
title_3: Director of the Institute for Global Studies
biography: Saïd Amir Arjomand is a renowned Middle East expert and scholar whose fields of study include Islamic Rule of Law, the Arab Revolution of 2011, Egypt and Iran.  He focuses on the integration of social theory and regional studies. Read bio

name: Jonathan Anzalone
title_1: Professor/Assistant Director of the Center for News Literacy, Assistant Undergraduate Director for the School of Journalism
biography: Jonathan Anzalone’s expertise is in news literacy, writing, and history. He’s presented his research at conferences hosted by the American Historical Association (AHA), the Boston Environmental History Seminar, the American Society for Environmental History (ASEH), the Yale University Working Group on Global Environmental History, and the New York State Historical Association (NYSHA). He is currently working on a book based on his dissertation: “Creating a Modern Wilderness Playground: The Transformation of the Adirondack State Park, 1920 - 1980" which will be published by the University of Massachusetts Press.

name: Jennifer L. Anderson
biography: Jennifer L. Anderson's research focuses on the environmental and cultural history of the Caribbean and the greater Atlantic World in the 17th -19th centuries. Her book Mahogany: The Costs of Luxury in Early America (Harvard Univ Press, 2012) examines the colonial trade in tropical timbers from the Caribbean to North America. Her new work explores New York's early Caribbean connections. She also examines how Long Island became a venue where Native peoples, European settlers, and enslaved Africans encountered each other during the colonial period. Drawing on her background as a museum curator, exhibition developer, and researcher, Jennifer serves as advisor to many historical and cultural organizations.

name: Joan Alpers
biography: Joan Alpers specializes in child life and art therapy. She has more than 30 years of experience in making children’s hospital visits more comfortable, anxiety-free and, in many cases, fun. By incorporating medical play, which lets children use real or toy medical equipment, Joan helps prepare children for their medical treatment. She is a former president of Child Life of Greater NY.

name: Bassem Allam
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Bassem Allam’s research is centered on interactions between marine mollusks and waterborne microorganisms in general and, in particular, the framework of host-pathogen interactions. He also studies the mechanisms of resistance to pathogens and diseases, and the effect of environmental factors on these interactions. His research also includes a strong applied component aimed at enhancing knowledge and development of mitigation strategies for diseases affecting local shellfish species.

name: Eric S. Zolov
biography: Eric Zolov is a specialist in Latin American history, with research interests focused on the interplay between culture, politics, and international relations in twentieth-century Latin America, with a particular emphasis on the Cold War period. His research seeks to make connections between ideological articulations, consumptive practices, and broadly defined notions of power. He is co-editor of a documentary collection on US-Latin America relations, and has a particular expertise in Mexico, the subject of his next book.

name: Gregory Zelinsky
biography: Gregory Zelinsky's work attempts to integrate cognitive, computational, and neuroimaging techniques to better understand a broad range of visual cognitive behaviors, including search, object representation, working memory, and scene perception. He has extensive experience studying how people move their eyes as they search for familiar targets, such a favorite coffee mug, in addition to targets defined by only a category of object, such as a chair. He has built computer models describing both of these search behaviors.

name: Vincent Yang
title_1: Chair of Department of Medicine, President of Stony Brook Internists, Professor of Medicine, Physiology and Biophysics
biography: Vincent Yang is an internationally renowned physician scientist with a focus on the understanding and treatment of gastrointestinal malignancies. He is also a pioneer in the cloning and characterization of Krüppel-like factors (KLFs), a group of proteins with important physiologic functions. One of the KLFs that Dr. Yang's group identified, KLF4, has gained significant attention due to its ability to convert somatic cells to induced pleuripotenti stem cells (iPSC) with remarkable therapeutic potential.

name: Kevin Zacharoff
biography: Dr. Kevin Zacharoff is a chronic pain expert.  He is a member of the Anesthetic and Analgesic Drug Products Advisory Committee for the Food and Drug Administration, a Board Certified Anesthesiologist with more than 30 years of clinical practice experience in Anesthesiology and Pain medicine, Dr. Zacharoff  is the co-author of "The PainEDU.org Manual : A Pocket Guide to Pain Management and Managing Chronic Pain with Opioids in Primary Care."

name: Karina Anne Yager
title_3: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Concurrently a researcher for NASA, Karina Yager's research focuses on the impacts of climate change in mountain environments. She applies interdisciplinary methods to her research, including remote sensing of land cover and land-use change and the socio-ecological study of high-altitude vegetation, mountain peatland systems and indigenous pastoral communities. Her current research project, funded by NASA-ROSES, is focused on the impact of disappearing tropical glaciers on pastoral agriculture in the Andes of South America.  Read bio

name: William Worek
title_1: Associate Professor of Research and Graduate Studies
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: William Worek’s research interests are in the aspects of heat and mass transfer processes as they apply energy systems in commercial and industrial applications. He has investigated liquid absorption processes in both open- and closed-cycle systems and methods to enhance heat transport in refrigeration systems. He also has worked on design and operational strategies to realize net zero energy buildings in northern climates.

name: Patricia C. Wright
biography: Patricia C. Wright founded Centre ValBio, a modern research campus in the rainforest of Madagascar where she has combined her research with efforts to preserve the country’s endangered forests and the many species of plants and animals they harbor. She was the driving force behind the creation of Ranomafana National Park, a 106,000-acre World Heritage Site there, which is home to many endangered species, including several species of lemur that she almost certainly saved from extinction.

name: Stanislaus S. Wong
biography: Stanislaus Wong’s research is primarily focused on developing sustainable strategies for producing novel classes of nanomaterials, possessing unique opto-electronic, catalytic, and magnetic properties.  These nanoscale structures consist of “tunable” building blocks measuring 1 to 1000 nanometers (i.e. millionths of a millimeter). His goal is to broaden the impact and applicability of nanostructures in areas as diverse as electronics and medicine, with a special emphasis on energy-related devices, such as solar cells, fuel cells, and batteries.

name: Joseph D. Warren
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Joseph Warren’s research involves the use of underwater acoustics, a non-invasive way to measure and study a variety of oceanographic processes.  One focus of his research is the foraging behavior of apex predators such as marine mammals and other ocean predators. A current area of study is the increase in nearshore humpback and other whale sightings along the coast of New York after decades of only rare whale sightings. He believes these increased sightings could be due to an increase in large aggregations of Atlantic menhaden (a prey fish also called bunker) that occur in the area and the fact that humpback whale populations appear to be increasing due to protection laws.

name: Lianxing Wen
biography: Lianxing Wen  is a seismologist (studies earthquakes), geodynamicist and planetary scientist. His research is directed toward understanding the structure, dynamics, composition and evolution of the Earth and other planets. Lianxing’s work has fundamentally changed our understanding of the structure and dynamical processes of the Earth's mantle, outer core and inner core, and the boundaries between them.

name: Ya Wang
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Ya Wang’s research interests span a broad range of topics in the fields of adaptive and multifunctional structures with integrated wireless sensing, energy harvesting and dynamic control using smart materials.

name: Wayne Waltzer
title_1: Urologist/Kidney Transplantation; Professor and Chairman, Department of Urology; Director of the Renal Transplant Service
biography: Dr. Waltzer was a member of the original team that performed the first kidney transplant on Long Island. He has expertise in oncology, including prostate, kidney, and bladder cancer, as well as kidney transplantation.

name: James Vosswinkel
title_1: Chief of Trauma, Emergency Surgery and Surgical Critical Care; Assistant Professor of Surgery; Medical Director, Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU)
biography: Dr. Vosswinkel’s specialties include surgical management of injured patients (all aspects of traumatology); management of diseases of the gastrointestinal and endocrine systems; treatment of soft tissue disease; repair of hernias, including incisional/ventral, inguinal, umbilical, and other types; appendectomy; cholecystectomy; conventional and minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery; and pre- and post-operative critical care of adult surgical patients.

name: Harold W Walker
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: With a focus on understanding surface chemical processes in natural and engineered systems and an emphasis on clean water, Harold Walker’s research areas include predicting the fate and transport of manufactured nanomaterials  and other “emerging” contaminants in groundwater, lakes, oceans, and water treatment plants. His work also includes developing novel membrane treatment systems, determining the vulnerability of the public to cyanotoxins in finished drinking water, and understanding the environmental implications of energy extraction and electricity production.

name: Frederick M. Walter
biography: Frederick Walter is a galactic astronomer. His research interests include novae, neutron stars, Solar and stellar activity (flares and coronal mass ejections, and their effects on the Earth), and the formation of sun-like and low mass stars, brown dwarfs, and exoplanets. He has been consulted about Mars and Pluto. He observes regularly, using observatories in Chile and Arizona, and is a guest investigator on the Hubble Space Telescope and the Chandra and XMM-Newton X-ray observatories.

name: Arnout van de Rijt
biography: Arnout van de Rijt's work exploits novel data collection opportunities enabled by present-day communication technology to answer longstanding questions about the origins of social order and societal inequality. His research topics include online social networks, crowd-funding, immigrant assimilation, online petitioning, peer collaboration on Wikipedia, fame, PED use in sports, residential segregation and intimate relationships.

name: John True
biography: John True studies developmental and evolutionary genetics and works with Drosophila fruit flies to study the developmental genetics of adaptation and speciation (the process by which new species are formed). He is an expert in the genetics and development of insect pigmentation and has published over 30 papers in the areas of the genetics of new species formation and species differences in pigmentation, behavior, and morphology. This work helps establish the role of gene regulatory diversity in the origin and diversity of visible traits among species.

name: Katheryn C. Twiss
biography: Katheryn Twiss’ research focuses on social and economic practices in early agricultural societies. She uses faunal remains to study past human-animal interactions. Her research involves issues such as the origins of domestication, the cultural implications of different animal management strategies, and the integration of wild and domestic resources. She is also interested in the archaeology of food by concentrating on the social aspects of food production and use. She is currently conducting research and is the Co-Director of the faunal analysis laboratory at the Neolithic site of Çatalhöyük in Turkey.

name: Nancy Tomes
biography: Nancy Tomes is an American historian with a focus on the intersection between expert knowledge and popular understandings of the body and disease. She’s the award-winning author of four books, including The Gospel of Germs: Men, Women and the Microbe in American life, (1998) about the popularization of the germ theory of disease, and Remaking the American Patient which was awarded the prestigious Bancroft Prize in 2017, which examines an in depth research in the popular yet largely unexamined concept origin of patients “shopping” for health care. She’s also developed “Medicine and Madison Avenue”, a website in collaboration with Duke University Library’s Special Collections, which explores the complex history of health related advertising. Her current research focus is on the history of psychiatry, the impact of the Internet on doctor-patient interactions, and a comparative look at the medical consumerism in other countries.

name: Joshua Teplitsky
biography: Joshua Teplitsky's work focuses on ​ Jewish history in the German-speaking lands of the Holy Roman Empire and Habsburg monarchy in the early modern period (16th–18th centuries) with an emphasis on the city of Prague. Additionally, he studies the relationship between Jews and their surrounding societies -- as well as the social, cultural, and intellectual exchanges between Jews and Christians. Joshua is also an expert in ​the study of books, printing, and media, and digital humanities.

name: David Thanassi
department: Department of Molecular Genetics and Microbiology
title_2: Department of Molecular Genetics and Microbiology
biography: David Thanassi’s research focuses on understanding strategies used by bacteria to cause disease.  He has a particular interest in bacterial virulence factors, understanding how these virulence factors are secreted by the bacteria and how they function to allow bacteria to cause disease. His lab is also interested in exploiting the understanding of bacterial virulence factors to develop novel alternatives to antibiotics.

name: Benjamin Tausig
biography: Benjamin Tausig is an expert on the topic of how political upheaval shapes musicians, their music and performance art.  Thailand’s  2010-11 “Red Shirt” movement is his special interest.  He has written about  the lives and music of Thai protest musicians and how they were  affected by the Thai military’s psychological operations unit.

name: Apostolos Tassiopoulos
title_1: Vascular Surgeon, Chief of the Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery, Program Director of the Vascular Surgery Residency and the Surgical Skills Simulation Center, Co-Director of the Aortic Center
biography: Dr. Apostolos Tassiopoulos has expertise in minimally invasive (endovascular) management of abdominal and thoracic aortic aneurysms, aortic dissections, vascular trauma, lower extremity vascular disease (PAD), treatment of venous disease (including minimally invasive percutaneous closure for varicose veins), treatment and prevention of deep-vein-thrombosis, inferior vena cava filters, thrombolysis, renal and mesenteric artery stenosis, surgery for stroke prevention (carotid stenting and endarterectomy), dialysis access procedures, and limb-salvaging procedures. He also has experience with surgical quality improvement programs and with improving safety of surgical patients.

name: Henry J. Tannous
biography: Henry J. Tannous has established an advanced clinical practice in adult cardiac surgery, as well as a focused interest in the most effective and advanced techniques for minimally invasive surgery for certain lung cancers,  and  transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). He also concentrates on the latest surgical methods to correct atrial fibrillation and other arrhythmias.

name: Allen R. Tannenbaum
department: Computer Science and Applied Mathematics & Statistics
title_2: Computer Science and Applied Mathematics & Statistics
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Allen Tannenbaum’s fields of interest include cancer research, medical imaging, computational computer vision, image processing, robust control, mathematical systems theory, bioinformatics, semiconductor fabrication processes, and robotics. His work in computer vision has earned him numerous awards, and he holds four patents in medical imaging and computer vision Recently, he has developed mathematical formulas to understand and quantify the ability of cancer cells to adapt and develop resistance to assist in the treatment of cancer.

name: Mark Talamini
title_1: Professor and Chairman of Surgery, Chief of Surgical services, Founding Director of Medical Innovation Institute, President of Stony Brook Surgical Associates, Co-Director of SOAR Collaborative
biography: Mark Talamini is recognized for his expertise in advanced laparoscopic surgery. He specializes in gastrointestinal surgery, with an emphasis on the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis). He is considered a pioneer in minimally invasive abdominal surgery, and is recognized as one of the leading authorities on laparoscopic and robotic-assisted surgery in the United States.

name: Wendy K. Tang
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Wendy Tang’s current research interests are in wireless sensor networks, communication networks, and graph theory applications, with a specific interest in the development of efficient routing protocols for large and dense wireless sensor networks. As Associate Provost for Online Learning at Stony Brook, she is an expert in online educational development, and developed the online Bachelor of Science Program in Electrical Engineering, which has been recognized as one of the best in the nation.

name: Katarina Supe-Markovina
title_1: Pediatric Nephrologist, Assistant Professor of Clinical Pediatrics, Director of Pediatric Hypertension Center
biography: Dr. Katarina Supe-Markovina has a special interest in pediatric hypertension, in particular 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, as well as congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

name: Larry Swanson
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Larry Swanson has worked primarily with marine pollution issues in the coastal ocean, and contributes to environmental policy debates concerning ocean dumping, marine debris, and sewage discharge criteria, among others. His broad research interests include understanding and identifying the appropriate use of the ocean as part of a comprehensive waste management strategy. He also views the development of materials made from post-consumer waste into new products as a promising and growing means of reusing waste material.
areas_of_expertise_3: recycling and reuse of waste materials

name: Kathleen Stergiopoulos
title_1: Cardiologist and Associate Professor of Medicine, Co-Director of the Woman's Heart Program
biography: Kathleen Stergiopoulos has a strong interest in patient care for all forms of cardiovascular disease, including pregnancy and heart disease, women's cardiac issues, including primary prevention, coronary artery disease, and valvular heart disease. Her research interests include women's cardiac disease, pregnancy and cardiac disease, and use of new echocardiographic technologies. She has published on pregnancy and heart disease, outcomes in patients with stable coronary disease, and echocardiographic techniques.

name: Steven Stern
biography: Steven Stern is an expert in labor economics, health economics, economics of aging, mental health, long-term care and the family and industrial organization and econometrics. His research involves increasing our understanding of some phenomenon in the real world by using innovative econometric methods. He has recently been cited in the news for his research that can help predict divorce.

name: Shikaripur N. Sridhar
biography: Shikaripur N. Sridhar is an expert on the languages and cultures of India and South Asia, and has done pioneering research on the structural, sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic aspects of bilingualism and language interaction in individuals and society. Additional areas of his research include the switching and mixing of languages, the acquisition and use of English as a second language in multilingual countries communities, and the nature and functions of new varieties of the language, such as Indian English.
areas_of_expertise_5: literatures of India and South Asia

name: Mary Squillace
title_3: School of Health Technology and Management
biography: Mary Squillace’s areas of clinical expertise include traumatic brain injury, spinal cord injury, neonatal intensive care, and pediatrics with a specialty in early intervention in ages 0 to 3 years of age. She is currently involved involved in research with a team of neurologists that is assessing and investigating primary factors related to the disease of pediatric multiple sclerosis.

name: Fotis Sotiropoulos
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Fotis Sotiropoulos’ research uses computational algorithms that enable virtual experiments and simulation-based engineering science for fluid mechanics in real-life environmental, renewable energy, and biological applications. His research projects have included work focused on wind turbines and farms, marine hydrokinetic turbines and farms, simulation of turbulence in natural aquatic environments, and medical devices and virtual surgery. One area of his medical research includes the fluid mechanics of heart valves and their replacements.

name: Scott A. Smolka
biography: Scott Smolka has made fundamental contributions in the areas of probabilistic process algebra, computational model checking, and cardiac-cell modeling and analysis. He currently leads the “CyberCardia” project, a virtual-heart platform to improve and accelerate medical-device development and testing at a far lower cost than existing methods. CyberCardia also can be used to design optimal, patient-specific device therapies, thereby lowering the risk to the patient.

name: Oleg Smirnov
biography: Oleg Smirnov’s areas of expertise  and research interests include world politics, politics of climate change, cooperation, computational modeling (agent-based modeling, geographic information systems, evolutionary dynamics) and behavioral economics (altruistic punishment, collective risk social dilemmas). He is currently working on a computational model of social consequences of climate change, and recently published a paper that reveals climate change, not population growth, plays the main role in predicting population exposure to extreme droughts.

name: Peter Small
biography: Peter Small’s expertise includes tuberculosis and global health. He has done seminal work on clinical, epidemiologic, evolutionary, and genetic aspects of tuberculosis. He has deep expertise in translating cutting edge science into drugs, diagnostics and vaccines as well as the business and public health processes to get innovative tools to those in need. He is currently leading the Global Health Institute’s health science research that spans from the molecular level to point of delivery, and encompasses fundamental work on ecology, developmental economics, and disease, largely focused on Madagascar.

name: Hal A Skopicki
title_1: Cardiologist, Director, Heart Failure and Cardiomyopathy Center, Co-Director, Mechanical Ventricular Assist Device (VAD) Program Stony Brook Heart Institute
biography: Hal Skopicki specializes in advanced/complex cardiac disease involving the heart muscle, valves, arteries, or overall heart function. His expertise includes the diagnosis and treatment of all forms of heart failure, and extends to cutting-edge technologies as a principal researcher for investigations involving stem cells, genetic analysis, and state-of-the-art medical therapy. He regularly treats patients with severe heart failure and is an expert in assessing their options.

name: Gary Sherman
biography: Gary Sherman’s area of expertise is social hierarchy and its role in the inner workings of groups and organizations. The specific topics he explores include the various forms and bases of social hierarchy (e.g., power, status, moral standing);  the factors and processes that create and sustain hierarchy (e.g., social evaluation, status seeking, competition); and how social hierarchies and the conditions they create impact the thoughts, actions, and biology of the individuals embedded within them.

name: Radu Sion
biography:

--> Radu Sion's research focuses on cybersecurity and he is the director of the University's National Security Institute. He also focuses in large-scale and cloud computing and green computing. Examples of some of his project areas include secure storage and data management, cellular and wireless security, data privacy mechanisms, digital rights management, identity management and applied cryptography.

name: Steven S. Skiena
biography: Steven Skiena’s research focuses on analyzing large-scale text streams such as news, blogs, and social media to identify cultural trends around the world's people, places, and things. He and his team developed computational methods to measure fame and significance of historical figures by analyzing Wikipedia, which is detailed in the book he co- authored,  Who's Bigger?  His research interests also include algorithm design and its applications to biology.

name: Shyam Sharma
biography: Shyam Sharma is a scholar and teacher of writing and rhetoric who studies academic writing and communication at the intersection of the arts and sciences. He is currently documenting how U.S. universities are facilitating the growth and success of international graduate students as writers and scholars in their disciplines and into the professions. A former lecturer at the Tribhuvan University of Nepal, he is also an expert on issues about Nepal and South Asia.

name: John J. Shea
biography: John Shea’s research focuses on the archaeology of human origins and evolution during the Pleistocene Ice Ages. His interests include early hominid adaptive radiations, the origin of Homo sapiens, the extinction of the Neanderthals, and lithic (stone tool) technology. He has investigated these subjects through projects in Israel, Jordan, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Kenya.  An expert stone-tool-maker, Shea uses the results of experiments using stone tools to improve archaeological methods for reconstructing prehistoric human behavior.

name: Chris L. Sellers
biography: Christopher Sellers is a historian with a long-standing interest in the environmental, cultural, and health history of the 20th-century United States, and the ways this history has compared with that of other parts of the world. His research concentrates on the history of occupational and environmental health, of cities and suburbs, of industrial development and its hazards, and of the environmental movement. Chris is co-editor of Dangerous Trade: Histories of Industrial Hazard across a Globalizing World and is author of Crabgrass Crucible: Suburban Nature and the Rise of Environmentalism in 20th-Century America , as well as a forthcoming history of the lead and petrochemical industries in Texas and Mexico. He is also a trained physician.

name: Carrie L Shandra
biography: Carrie Shandra's research interests include the effect of disability on the transition to adulthood, as well as on participation in unpaid work such as household labor, child care, and volunteering. She also studies internships and the impact of school-to-work programs on young people's employment. Read bio

name: Richard Scriven
title_1: Pediatric Surgeon/Trauma; Associate Professor of Surgery; Director, General Surgery Residency
biography: Dr. Scriven’s expertise includes surgical management of congenital and acquired anomalies/diseases of the neck, chest, abdomen, anorectum, and soft tissues in children (newborns to adolescents aged 17 years), including, but not limited to, congenital anomalies of the esophagus. He’s also interested in necrotizing enterocolitis; inguinal hernias; undescended testes; appendicitis; tumors of the kidneys, adrenal glands, gastrointestinal tract, lymphatics, and soft tissues; surgical consultation in pediatric trauma; and minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery.

name: Mark Schweitzer
title_1: Radiologist, Chairman, Department of Radiology, Professor of Radiology
biography: Mark Schweitzer is one of the initial developers of Musculoskeletal MRI, having authored nearly 400 peer reviewed papers, 60 book chapters, and 4 books on musculoskeletal imaging. He has been invited to lecture in over 35 countries, and is currently the editor-in-chief of the major, international MRI journal. In addition, his work on diabetic foot disease has led to drastic reductions in amputations around the world.

name: Nicholas Scibetta
title_1: Vice President for Communications and Marketing
biography: Nicholas Scibetta is a seasoned global communications executive who is responsible for the University’s overarching global communications, brand strategy and visual identity. He is driving the vision and direction for the organization’s global communications and marketing functions across the University, Stony Brook Medicine and Stony Brook University Hospital system, overseeing and managing marketing, strategic communications, media/public relations, crisis and issues, content/publications, digital, social, and advertising. In his previous roles, he has overseen national and international communications programs for Fortune 500 clients.

name: Susan Schuval
title_1: Pediatric Allergist/Immunologist, Chief, Division of Pediatric Allergy and Immunology, Fellow of the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology
biography: Susan Schuval’s areas of expertise are primary immunodeficiency disease, food allergy, and Eosinophilic esophagitis (an inflammatory condition of the esophagus). Her research interests include improving anaphylaxis knowledge for residents-in-training via simulation laboratory training, and studying risk factors for Eosinophilic esophagitis in young children.

name: Michael Schuster
department: Stony Brook Cancer Center, Stem Cell Transplantation and Hematologic Malignancy Program
title_1: Transplant Specialist, Hematologist/Oncologist, Professor of Medicine, Team Leader and Director, Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Transplantation, Director, Hematologic Malignancies Program
title_3: Stem Cell Transplantation and Hematologic Malignancy Program
biography: Michael Schuster is a renowned hematologic cancer expert who has been the principal investigator for more than 200 clinical trials over the past 20 years and has worked extensively in the area of bone marrow transplantation, cytokines, hematologic malignancies, oncology new drug development, and cachexia. His research interests include improving stem cell transplant outcomes, new drug development in hematologic malignancies, lymphoma and leukemia, therapeutic uses of cytokines and immunotherapy, novel conditioning regimens in bone marrow, and blood stem cell transplantation, as well as the role of pro-inflammatory cytokines in geriatric and cancer cachexia, anemia, and in other disease states.

name: Howard Schneider
title_1: Founding Dean of the School of Journalism
biography: Howard Schneider is the founding Dean of the School of Journalism and Executive Director of the University's Center for News Literacy, which developed the nation's first undergraduate course in how to be a discerning news consumer. The news literacy course has been completed by more than 15,000 students in the U.S. and in 10 countries. Before transitioning to higher education in 2006, Howie spent 35 years as a working journalist for Newsday, a top-tier New York newspaper -- where for 18 years he served as managing editor and then editor. Under his editorial leadership, the newspaper won eight Pulitzer Prizes and became one of the first newspapers in the nation to create news websites.

name: Steven Sandoval
title_1: Surgeon, Emergency/Trauma, Assistant Professor of Surgery, Medical Director, Burn Center
biography: Steven Sandoval’s primary area of expertise is burn surgery, as well as evaluating burn victims, facial trauma, critical care, and general surgery.

name: Marianna Savoca
biography: Marianna Savoca leads a centralized career service for a all students and alumni of all majors, class years, and career intentions. She has held leadership roles in several career development organizations, consults for university career centers domestically and internationally, and has been recognized with several awards for excellence, including a Fulbright Award for Administrators in International Education, the NSEE Rising Leader Award, and the SUNY Chancellor’s Award for Excellence in Professional Service.

name: Warren C. Sanderson
biography: Warren Sanderson’s research interests are in population-economic interactions, which include probabilistic population forecasting, measuring aging in ways that take life expectancy change into account, and the effects of education and other demographic changes on economic growth. He is also a senior research scholar at the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Austria.

name: Nicole S. Sampson
biography: Nicole Sampson’s research focuses on proteins and polymers. She studies how proteins function in human and microbial biology, and how small molecules can alter protein function to improve the human condition. She develops methods for precision synthesis of polymers. In particular, her research is aimed at finding new treatments for tuberculosis and cancer and to understand molecular reasons for infertility.

name: John Barry Ryan
biography: John Ryan's research focuses on political communication, social networks, campaigns, and voting behavior. His recent papers have explored how people's social networks affect which candidates they support and their partisanship, as well as how candidates strategical talk about issues in campaigns.
areas_of_expertise_5: influence of social networks on voting

name: Carl Safina
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Carl Safina, a marine ecologist and author of various books, including a recent bestseller about what animals think and feel, is one of the nation’s most esteemed environmental writers. As an ecologist, his achievements include leading campaigns to ban high-seas driftnets, achieve passage of a UN global fisheries treaty, and reduce albatross and sea turtle drownings on commercial fishing lines. He now writes about the troubled relationship between humanity and the living world.

name: Gabrielle Antoinette Russo
biography: Gabrielle Russo’s research focuses on the functional morphology, the relationship between structure and function, and evolution of the primate musculoskeletal (locomotor) skeleton system. In her research, she employs comparative, evolutionary, and developmental approaches, and a number of morphometric (form measuring) techniques. Her research program aims to answer questions regarding three major transitions in the axial skeleton that occurred during hominoid (apes and humans) evolution: tail loss, the adoption of upright trunk posture, and adaptations to bipedal (two-legged) locomotion.

name: Delaney Ruston
biography: A physician who works with the underserved, Delaney Ruston is also producer and director of documentaries that address mental health and ethical dilemmas in doctor-patient communication. Her multi-award winning feature documentaries include UNLISTED: A Story of Schizophrenia, and HIDDEN PICTURES:  A Personal Journey into Global Mental Health, both of which have screened internationally and have aired on PBS stations nationwide. Her new documentary, SCREENAGERS: Growing Up In The Digital Age, was released in early 2016.

name: Naomi Rosenthal
biography: Naomi Rosenthal has written about 19 th Century women’s organizational networks, leader-member conflict in protest organizations, and social movements. Her most recent book, Spinster Tales and Womanly Possibilities, looks at changing conceptions of spinsterhood in modern American culture.

name: Deanne Rogers
biography: Deanne Rogers is anexpert in the surface of the planet Mars. To better understand the volcanic, aqueous and sedimentary history of the martian crust and surface, she uses  analyzes images and infrared data returned from Mars and the Moon. This work is done in her remote sensing facility located in the University's Center for Planetary Exploration, which opened in mid-2016.

name: Clinton Rubin
title_1: Distinguished Professor, Chair of Department of Biomedical Engineering, Director of Center for Biotechnology
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Clinton Rubin’s work is targeted towards understanding the cellular mechanisms responsible for the growth, healing, and homeostasis of musculoskeletal tissues such as bone, cartilage, tendon, ligament, and muscle, as well as the formation of adiposity. He has published over 200 peer-reviewed papers and 50 book chapters on the use of physical stimuli in controlling physiologic processes and the musculoskeletal system, and holds 22 patents, with 14 pending, in the areas of wound repair, stem cell regulation, and treatment of bone disease.

name: Eva Rodriguez
title_3: School of Health Technology and Management
biography: Eva Rodriguez is a  pediatric occupational therapist who’s had a clinical practice for the past 27 years. She has research experience in transition issues for parents and youth who are diagnosed with pediatric multiple sclerosis. During the past several years, her clinical interests have also included driver rehabilitation for people with disabilities.

name: Theresa Robertson
biography: Theresa Robertson’s research focuses on how people choose who to associate with and who to avoid, as well as how people detect and minimize the costs of social exclusion when it happens. Her research has been supported by the National Science Foundation and she has published in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Psychological Science, and Evolution and Human Behavior.

name: John Rizzo
biography: John Rizzo is a health economist whose research interests include applied microeconomic studies of physician and pharmaceutical markets, the application of econometric methods to clinical outcomes research, and pharmacoeconomic evaluations of medical treatments and technologies. He consults for leading healthcare and government organizations, and has testified as an economics expert in cases involving the pharmaceutical and hospital industries. He also is the chief economist of the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group.

name: Basil Rigas
title_1: Gastroenterologist, Chief, Division of Cancer Prevention, Vice President of Business Development, Dean for Clinical Affairs, William and Jane Knapp Professor of Pharmacology, Professor of Medicine
biography: Basil Rigas is a specialist in gastroenterology. In recent years, his focus has been on cancer prevention. He is recognized internationally for his research on the prevention of colon cancer using traditional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), nitric-oxide-donating NSAIDs, and other pharmacological agents. He also has pioneered the application of infrared spectroscopy to biology with an emphasis on cancer, and holds several relevant patents. A new area of his work concerns the use of nanotechnology in cancer prevention and treatment.

name: Steven Reiner
biography: Steven Reiner is a former CBS NEWS “60 Minutes” Emmy Award winning producer . He also served as Executive Producer of National Public Radio’s (NPR) “All Things Considered,” and as Senior Editor of NPR's Science Reporting Unit. He specializes in making complex scientific issues understandable to the general public and works with scientists, health professionals, and science students. In addition to his popular workshops called "Distilling your Message,” and “Dealing with the Media," he is also one of two presenters of a "Coursera MOOC," co-produced by the Center for News Literacy at the Stony Brook School of Journalism, and the University of Hong Kong.

name: Kevin A. Reed
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Kevin Reed’s research interests include understanding the capability of global climate models to simulate extreme weather events and the impact of model design choices on the simulation of such extremes in a global context. One specific area of his research has focused on the ability of the National Center for Atmospheric Research’s Community Atmosphere Model (CAM) to simulate tropical cyclones at high-resolutions. Additionally, he studies how extreme events, including tropical cyclones, may change as a result of a changing climate.

name: E. Troy Rasbury
biography: Geologist Troy Rasbury’s research focuses on time resolution in sedimentary rock formations.  Using isotopes and trace elements to address questions of age, provenance and process, she has explored rock formations throughout the United States.

name: Eric Rashba
title_1: Cardiologist, Director, Heart Rhythm Center, Professor of Medicine
biography: Eric Rashba is an expert in the evaluation and management of all arrhythmia conditions.  His clinical practice focuses on atrial fibrillation management, including ablation and stroke prevention, device therapy for cardiac arrhythmias, and extraction of chronically implanted pacemaker and defibrillator leads.  Research interests include new mechanisms of QT prolongation, and prediction and prevention of sudden cardiac death.

name: Svetlozar Rachev
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Svetlozar Rachev  works in the field of mathematical finance probability theory and statistics, and is one of the world’s foremost authorities in the application of heavy-tailed (larger probability of getting very large values) distributions in finance. He created an algorithm that is a statistically highly accurate risk analytics methodology to model and measure financial risks. He is the author of 14 books and over 300 published articles on finance, econometrics, probability, statistics, and actuarial science. Read bio

name: Suparna Rajaram
biography: Suparna Rajaram’s research focuses on memory and amnesia. In one line of research, she studies the transmission of memory in groups and social networks. In a second line of research, testing both people with intact memory and with organic amnesia, she studies the differences between implicit and explicit memory, the distinction between episodic and semantic memory, and how attention modulates long-term memory. In a third line of research, she studies the nature of emotional memory.

name: Aurora Dawn Pryor
title_1: Professor of Surgery, Vice Chair for Clinical Affairs, Chief of Bariatric, Foregut and Advanced GI Surgery Division, Director of Bariatric/Metabolic Weight Loss Center and Minimally Invasive/Bariatric Surgery Fellowship
biography: Aurora Pryor's research is focused on advancing laparoscopic bariatric and upper GI surgery techniques and outcomes, and on use of new technology. She has performed more than 1,400 bariatric procedures among her over 3,000 surgical cases during the last 16 years. She is a regional expert in benign gastroesophageal diseases, including minimally invasive techniques for the management of reflux and swallowing disorders like complex revisional surgery. A nationally renowned scholar and researcher as well as surgeon, Dr. Pryor holds patents for surgical technologies.

name: Roy Price
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Roy Price is an aqueous geochemist investigating the chemical evolution of hydrothermal vent fluids and groundwater. These themes overlap in that fluid chemistry is driven by water-rock reactions. He focuses on shallow-sea vents, where he evaluates toxic metal cycling, bioaccumulation of arsenic, associated microbial communities, and even the origin of life. He also investigates metal mobilization and nitrogen cycling in groundwater. He is currently Research Coordinator for the Center for Clean Water Technology, and conducts research related to the Long Island's nitrate pollution. Read bio
areas_of_expertise_5: toxic elements in coastal marine environments

name: Joseph M. Pierce
biography: Joseph M. Pierce specializes in 19th and turn-of-the-century Latin American literature and culture. He focuses on queer theory and kinship studies and investigates the mechanisms of power that have marginalized certain groups, such as sexual minorities, women, immigrants, and indigenous communities. He also collaborates with La Poderosa Media Project, a nonprofit that encourages youth empowerment and collaborative learning through community-based arts programs in Latin America and the United States.

name: Stephen Post
department: Director of the Center for Medical Humanities
title_2: Director of the Center for Medical Humanities
biography: Stephen Post is a bioethicist who has studied the relationship between altruism, compassion, happiness, healing and health to conclude that giving can lead to a happier, longer life. He is a pioneer in publishing works regarding ethical aspects of diseases such as Alzheimer’s, an important but neglected issue of the aging population. He is the Founding Director of The Center for Medical Humanities, Compassionate Care and Bioethics center at Stony Brook University.

name: Michael Peress
biography: Michael Peress developed a survey-based measure of district ideology for the House of Representatives, and used it to document and study ways in which patterns of candidate positioning depart from perfect representation. In another recent paper he co-authored, he explores how voters benchmark national economic growth either rewarding or punishing incumbents.

name: James Penna
title_1: Chief of Sports Medicine, Associate Professor
biography: James Penna specializes in the care of athletes and disorders of the knee, shoulder, and elbow. He’s a board-certified orthopaedic surgeon and is a team orthopaedic physician for Stony Brook University, Suffolk County Community College, and Dowling College. Read bio

name: Bradley Peterson
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_3: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Bradley Peterson’s research is focused on shallow coastal ecosystems (seagrasses, corals reefs, oysters reefs) to understand the role of of how these organisms influence their communities and how these interactions might affect community stability and resilience. Most of his work is with plant-animal interactions along the eastern coast of the U.S. One of his current projects is investigating the consequences of changing climate on Long Island south shore estuaries.

name: Michael L. Pearl
title_1: Professor and Director of Division of Gynecological Oncology, Vice Chairman of Research and Faculty Development, Director of Women's Cancer services
biography: Michael Pearl’s research interests are ovarian cancer, uterine cancer, and general gynecologic oncology. In addition to his clinical activities, he is the chairman of Stony Brook University’s Committee (B) on Research in Human Subjects. He is also the Principal Investigator at Stony Brook Medicine for NRG Oncology, a National Cancer Institute-funded cooperative research group dedicated to promoting excellence in the quality and integrity of scientific research.

name: Ramin V. Parsey
title_1: Professor and Chair of the Department of Psychiatry, Della Pietra Family Chair in Biomedical Imaging, Professor or Radiology, Director of PET Research, Co-Director of Neuroscience Institute
biography: Ramin Parsey, a “biological psychiatrist,” focuses on depression and dementia, utilizing novel tools of positron emission tomography (PET) and other cutting-edge brain imaging technologies. Ramin serves as a grant reviewer for the NIH Extramural Program for Autism Center Grants, the NIH Intramural Psychiatry Program, and for the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention . Ramin will continue to pursue his PET and other studies of the mechanisms by which antidepressants work, and to identify biomarkers of successful treatment.

name: Robert I. Parker
title_1: Professor, Vice Chair for Academic Affairs, Director
biography: Robert Parker’s particular expertise is in bleeding disorders, pediatric thrombosis disorders, and in the design and conduct of clinical trials. Under Dr. Parker’s direction, Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at Stony Brook has become a top regional program for cancer care. The program is part of the Children’s Oncology Group, an international organization of more than 220 pediatric oncology programs that sponsors the most promising treatments for childhood cancer through clinical trials.

name: Margaret Parker
title_1: Pediatrician, Director of Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU), Chief of Critical Care Division
biography: Dr. Margaret Parker is a pediatric critical care specialist with expertise in the management of shock, respiratory failure, and organ failure.

name: James Paci
biography: James Paci specializes in the care of athletes and disorders of the shoulder, elbow, and knee. He currently performs clinical and biomechanical research at the Stony Brook University School of Medicine. He is a team orthopaedic physician for Stony Brook University, Suffolk County Community College, Dowling College, and an orthopaedic team physician and consultant for many high schools on Long Island. He is board certified in Orthopaedic Surgery and holds an additional Certification in Orthopaedic Sports Medicine. Read bio

name: Lester G. Paldy
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Lester Paldy is a former Marine officer and member of U.S. nuclear weapon negotiating delegations in Geneva and at the UN. His work on nuclear weapons issues includes the threat posed by terrorists attempting to build and use an improvised nuclear device and the multilateral agreement signed by with Iran. He is a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and a consultant for several federal agencies.

name: Oyeronke Oyewumi
biography: Oyeronke Oyewumi's primary areas of expertise are gender and race. Other focal areas include feminism and social inequality. She is the author of the book,  The Invention of Women: Making an African Sense of Western Gender Discourses, for which she received a Distinguished Book Award from the Sex and Gender Section of the American Sociological Association. In 2014, she received the Distinguished Africanist Award by the New York African Studies Association.

name: Jennifer Osipoff
biography: Dr. Jennifer Osipoff is a board certified pediatric endocrinologist. She is particularly interested in clinical research involving management of diabetes mellitus and new diabetes management technology, such as closed hybrid loop insulin pump systems. Prior and ongoing research has involved investigating prospective memory in children with type 1 diabetes mellitus, assessing school nurses educational needs for caring for students with type 1 diabetes mellitus, and serving as the local primary investigator for national clinical trials involving insulin pumps and continuous glucose monitoring in pediatric patients.

name: Artem Oganov
title_1: Professor, Director of the Center for Materials by Design
biography: Artem Oganov is a highly acclaimed American and Russian crystallographer, chemist, physicist and mineorologist. He holds five patents and has published more than 180 peer-reviewed articles.  He is recognized for his work in computational materials discovery, as well as the effects of pressure on chemical bonding and the state of matter at extreme conditions (inside the Earth and other planets).  Dr. Oganov’s crystal structure prediction method became the basis of the USPEX code, used by more than 3,500 researchers worldwide.

name: Alexander M Orlov
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Alexander Orlov's principle research and teaching activities are in the development of novel materials for energy generation, structural applications and environmental protection. The majority of his research focuses on synthesis of novel catalytic nanomaterials and tuning their properties for environmental and energy related applications. Read bio

name: Brian J. O'Hea
title_1: Associate Professor of Clinical Surgery, Chief of Breast and Oncologic Surgery Division, Director of Carol M. Baldwin Breast Care Center
biography: Brian O’Hea’s research has focused on sentinel node biopsy in patients with breast cancer; local excision alone for selected patients with DCIS; STAR trial (NSABP chemoprevention trial); a pilot study of Docetaxal and Doxil with G-CSF as neoadjuvant treatment for patients with Stage II and III breast cancer. He is also a moderator of a weekly multidisciplinary breast conference.

name: Lina M. Obeid
title_1: Professor of Medicine, Dean for Research
biography: Lina Obeid, a physician-scientist and biomedical researcher, focuses her research on the biology of cancer, and mechanisms of cell growth and cell death.  Her interest is in bioactive sphingolipids—a class of lipids originally named for the mythical sphinx, because they were a riddle—and their role in regulating cancer cell growth and cell death. She is the Principal Investigator of numerous National Institutes of Health (NIH) grants related to lipid signaling.

name: Helmut Norpoth
biography: Helmut Norpoth is co-author of  The American Voter Revisited, covering the images of presidential candidates, party identification, and why Americans turn out to vote.  He has also written a book about public reactions to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, especially her economic and foreign policies.  Norpoth has designed models to forecast elections in the U.S., Britain, and Germany. His Primary Model correctly predicted Obama's re-election as early as February of 2012 and correctly predicted that Donald Trump would be the next President of the United States.

name: Janet A. Nye
department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_2: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
title_3: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Janet Nye’s research focuses on the effects of climate variability and climate change on fish, fisheries, and marine ecosystems. Specifically, she studies how climate and fishing interact to cause shifts in spatial distribution and abundance of fish and invertebrates in the Northwest Atlantic, including local fisheries in Long Island Sound and Great South Bay. Her research is used to inform how climate change may affect species that have been petitioned under the Endangered Species Act.

name: Nikolaos Nikiforakis
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Nick Nikiforakis' research focuses primarily on web security and privacy. He is the director of the PragSec lab (Pragmatic Security) and, together with his students, he conducts research in domain security, online tracking, and cyber crime. He often conducts large-scale security measurements, spanning hundreds of thousands of websites and applications, allowing him to quantify the state of security across different countries and sectors. He designs pragmatic security mechanisms that can be readily adopted by users, and uncovers issues that other researchers have, for years, overlooked.

name: Andrew Nicholson
biography: Andrew Nicholson's primary area of research is Indian philosophy and intellectual history, most recently focusing on Vedanta and Yoga philosophies in medieval and modern India. He also studies the history of the interpretation of Hinduism in the west and the transnational history of yoga.

name: Anne Moyer
biography: Anne Moyer studies psychosocial issues surrounding cancer and cancer risk. This work includes investigating ways to encourage women to engage in mammography screening and interventions to improve the quality of life of cancer patients. A related focus is medical decision making. This research includes studying the role of optimism in risk perception and treatment decisions, and decision making in veterinary medical contexts. Her third area of expertise is research methodology and the psychology of research participation. This work investigates, for example, how participant preferences interact with random assignment to treatment groups in clinical trials to affect engagement in treatment.
areas_of_expertise_1: Psychosocial issues surrounding cancer and cancer risk
areas_of_expertise_2: medical decision making in human and veterinary medical contexts

name: Kathleen Monahan
title_1: Associate Professor; Director, The Family Violence Education & Research Center; Director, Trauma Specialization
biography: Kathleen Monahan is the founder and director of the Family Violence Education and Research, and her areas of practice and research expertise include the effects of childhood sexual abuse, domestic violence, and severe trauma. She is a national and international lecturer on these topics and serves as a clinical consultant, expert witness, and forensic consultant. She has provided therapy, clinical supervision and consultation at several of the domestic violence shelters on Long Island.

name: Sharon Nachman
title_1: Chief of Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Director of the Office of Clinical Trials, Professor
biography: Sharon Nachman, an international leader in the area of pediatric infectious diseases and the treatment of children with AIDS, has been the principal investigator of more than 30 clinical trials of promising medicines for patients treated at the Medical Center. These include international trials in areas such as new vaccines, Lyme disease, and AIDS. She also directs the Maternal Child HIV/AIDS Program.

name: Joseph S. B. Mitchell
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: One of the country’s leaders in computational geometry, Joseph Mitchell works on the design, analysis, and implementation of efficient algorithms to solve geometric problems arising in robotics, sensor networks,computer graphics, visualization, air traffic management, manufacturing, and geographic information systems. One of his major applications was the development of algorithms in support of air traffic management, particularly for decision support tools to assist air traffic controllers reroute airplanes around inclement weather.

name: Joshua D Miller
title_1: Medical Director of Diabetes Care, Clinical Assistant Professor
biography: Dr. Joshua D. Miller is the Medical Director of Diabetes Care for Stony Brook Medicine and an Assistant Professor of Endocrinology & Metabolism in the Department of Medicine. He is dual board-certified in Internal Medicine and Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism.  Dr. Miller has vast experience helping people with diabetes to conquer the challenges of living with the disease; he has been living with type 1 diabetes for over twenty years. He is an expert in insulin pump and glucose sensor management as well as the transition of care to adult endocrinology for young adults with diabetes. Dr. Miller has a strong interest in population health and chronic disease. He serves as the Project Lead for the Suffolk Care Collaborative’s Diabetes Wellness and Self-Management initiative.

name: Scott M. McLennan
biography: Using the chemical composition of sedimentary rock and laboratory experiments that simulate a variety of sedimentary processes, Scott McLennan traces the evolution of the surfaces of both Earth and Mars. He has been a member of the science teams for the Mars rover and orbital missions, and he currently evaluates the chemical and mineralogical composition of Martian surface materials for NASA based on the return data from these missions.

name: Allison J. McLarty
title_1: Cardiothoracic Surgeon, Associate Program Director, Department of Surgery, Surgical Director, Left Ventricular Assist Device Program, Associate Professor of Surgery
biography: Allison McLarty treats adults with acquired heart disease who require surgery. Her special interests involve aortic surgery, including minimally invasive endovascular stenting for aortic aneurysms and surgical treatment of aortic dissection.  She is the surgical director of the Left Ventricular Assist Device (LVAD) program and uses leading-edge technology to treat severe heart failure with the new implantable heart pump.  She is active in the Women’s Heart Health program. She also treats patients with lung disease, including surgery for lung cancer.

name: Margaret M. Mcgovern
title_1: Pediatrician; Professor and Chairman, Department of Pediatrics; Physician-in-Chief, Stony Brook Children’s Hospital; Associate Dean for Ambulatory Operations; Chair of the Governing Board, Clinical Practice Management Plan at Stony Brook Medicine
biography: As the chair for the Department of Pediatrics, Dr. McGovern seeks to foster three critical missions: providing expert clinical care to pediatric patients, educating medical students and residents, and providing faculty with an environment that encourages and supports the conduct of outstanding research. She also has a strong interest in clinical genetics.

name: Celia J. Marshik
biography: Celia Marshik’s research focuses on British modernism, including the relationships between literature and the law and between modernism and cultural studies. Her teaching focuses on the relationship between modernism and the middlebrow, and the literature and culture of World War I. She is the author of  British Modernism and Censorship, as well as of articles on subjects that range from Virginia Woolf and copyright to the British secondhand clothing trade.

name: Sotirios Mamalis
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Dr. Sotirios Mamalis’ research focuses on modeling of advanced combustion modes in engines – such as Homogeneous Charge Compression Ignition (HCCI) – using conventional and alternative fuels, and development of physical models appropriate for powertrain simulation and analysis. Another of his interest areas is thermodynamic analysis of propulsion systems using exergy concepts, for identifying processes that promote efficient energy conversion.

name: Catherine Marrone
biography: Catherine Marrone's research and teaching focuses on a number of issues within the field of medical sociology, including social inequality in health and the sociology of aging. Additionally, her teaching addresses global issues related to infant and maternal mortality, fertility rates, and the cultural consequences of new forms of reproductive technology. She is the editor of Deeply Private, Incredibly Public: Readings on the Sociology of Human Reproduction, which explores these issues. Her current research includes the study of academic dishonesty on college campuses.

name: Heather J. Lynch
title_3: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
biography: Heather Lynch’s research is focused on uncovering the population dynamics and biogeographic distribution of penguins and other Antarctic seabirds, with a particular focus on untangling the effects of climate change, fishing, and tourism. Dr. Lynch has been at the forefront of using high-resolution satellite imagery to map penguin occupancy and abundance across Antarctica. These data are improving our understanding of penguin biology and their response to climate change.

name: Christian C. Luhmann
biography: Christian Luhmann’s research focuses on decision making and other complex behaviors.  To explore these behaviors he uses a variety of approaches, including behavioral experiments and computational modeling as well as neuroscientific methods such as electroencephalograms (EEGs) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). As a result, his work makes contact with a variety of disciplines, including psychology, behavioral economics, sociology, and computer science.

name: Benjamin J. Luft
title_1: Director and Principal Investigator, Stony Brook WTC Wellness Program
biography: Benjamin J. Luft, MD, is an internationally recognized expert in the treatment of Lyme disease and AIDS-related conditions, and was named the Edmund D. Pellegrino Professor of Medicine in 1987. Dr. Luft served as Chairman of the Department of Medicine from 1994 to 2006, and is now Director and Principal Investigator of the Stony Brook WTC Wellness Program.  A researcher and educator with diverse interests and achievements, Dr. Luft is a passionate spokesman who seeks to impart a reverence for humanity and a commitment to ethics in the practice of medicine.   Read bio

name: Jon P. Longtin
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Jon Longtin conducts research in the thermal sciences, with a focus on developing laser-based optical measurement techniques for temperature, concentration, and thermal properties; using ultra-fast lasers for precision materials processing and micromachining, and the development of sensors for harsh environments using direct-write thermal spray technology, including thermistors and thermocouples for temperature, resistance gauges, and humidity sensors.

name: Ken Lindblom
title_1: Associate Professor; Director of the English Teacher Education Program; Dean of the School of Professional Development
biography: An expert in teaching writing and English, in grades 6-12 and college, Ken Lindblom was named a 2012 Educator of Excellence, by the New York State English Council.  The co-author of  Making the Journey: Being and Becoming a Teacher of English Language Arts, (Fall 2016), he previously served as editor of English Journal (the oldest and most widely-read, peer-reviewed national journal devoted to teaching English in grades 6-12).  He holds New York State Permanent Teacher Certification in English, grades 7-12 and is a member of the Executive Committee of the national Conference on English Education.  A former member of the UUP Task Force on Teacher Education, Linblom is president of the Stony Brook Chapter of Phi Delta Kappa, the professional organization for K-12 educators. Ken has also developed the School of Professional Development’s digital badge program, which is quickly garnering interest from universities across the country, as they seek to implement this cutting-edge approach to micro-credentials and university/employer partnerships.
areas_of_expertise_5: digital badging at the college level

name: Ellen Li
title_1: Professor, Chief of the Division of Gasteroenterology and Hepatology, Director of Inflammatory Bowel Disease center
biography: Ellen Li’s focus is on prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of digestive diseases. Her current research interests are on defining the role of the gut microbiome in digestive diseases, particularly in inflammatory bowel diseases, colon cancer, and functional GI disorders, such as irritable bowel syndrome. Her specialty as a scientist is in translational research, which focuses on taking scientific discoveries and translating them into ways to help improve people’s health.

name: Daniel Levy
biography: Daniel Levy has been exploring the global diffusion of rights norms and their impact on questions of nation-state legitimacy, resulting in a monograph entitled "Human Rights and Memory." He is also co-editor of "The collective Memory Reader." He is one of the founders of The Initiative for Historical Social Science, a program that is run out of Stony Brook.

name: Karen Sobel Lojeski
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Karen Sobel Lojeski’s research focus is the impact of technology on people, including how technology impacts educational and business performance as well as overall well-being at the cognitive and emotional levels.  Through her research, she made an award-winning discovery of the phenomenon, “virtual distance,” which is a perceived distance that grows when people rely heavily on communication technology, resulting in major changes to learning, business performance, and a person’s ability to develop close personal relationships.

name: Marci Lobel
title_1: Professor; Principal Investigator of the Stony Brook Pregnancy Project; Director of the Doctoral Program in Social and Health Psychology
biography: Marci Lobel’s research focuses on stress, coping, and their effects on physical health, particularly women’s reproductive health.  Her research and teaching reveal common misconceptions about topics such as premenstrual syndrome, postpartum depression, menopause, and infertility.  ​Lobel and her collaborators conducted some of the first scientifically rigorous investigations to establish the adverse impact of prenatal maternal stress (PNMS) on human birth outcomes. Studies by her research team also address public health problems such as racial disparities in premature birth, rising rates of Cesarean delivery, and domestic abuse in pregnant women.

name: Matthew Daniel Lerner
biography: Matthew Lerner's research focuses on understanding emergence and “real world” implications of social problems in children and adolescents, particularly those with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). He also studies the development, evaluation, and dissemination of novel, evidence-based approaches for ameliorating those problems. Read bio
areas_of_expertise_6: psychosocial interventions for autism spectrum disorders
areas_of_expertise_7: social problems in children and adolescents

name: George Leibowitz
biography: ​Dr. George​ Leibowitz, PhD, LICSW, is an expert on opioid addiction and the negative impact these drugs can have. Leibowitz​ ​has been working as an interdisciplinary researcher, consultant, trainer, and licensed clinician in the related fields of adult and adolescent mental health and substance abuse assessment and treatment across the lifespan. He serves as cluster leader for Stony Brook University on a PCORI grant investigating the integration of evidence-supported Behavioral Health (BH) and primary care services. He was recently awarded a $1.8 million dollar HRSA grant, a collaboration between the Schools of Social Welfare and Nursing, to deliver behavioral health screening, brief intervention, and referral to underserved populations within Suffolk County, NY.

name: Craig Lehmann
title_3: School of Health Technology and Management
biography: Craig Lehmann, a registered clinical chemist, focuses on e-health technology (telemedicine) to respond to the socio-economic and health care concerns of developed and developing countries. He participates in national and international conferences lecturing on emerging technologies that improve the aging experience. He invented the RxMonitor+, a medication management device that assists clients and caregivers managing complex medication regimens and may help reduce the $100-300 billion spent in the U.S. each year for medication non-adherence issues.

name: Brian Lebowitz
biography: Brian K. Lebowitz, PhD ABPP is a Clinical Associate Professor of Neurology and the Director of Neuropsychology Training in the Neuropsychology Service at Stony Brook University Hospital.  He is board certified in neuropsychology and has published research in the areas of concussion and traumatic brain injury.

name: Matthew J. Lebo
title_1: Chair, Director of the Center for Behavioral Political Economy
biography: Matthew Lebo's research focuses on public opinion, presidential and congressional elections, and party politics in the United States and Great Britain. One of his recent papers explores how a high level of partisanship was costly in the 2010 elections. Another paper that he co-authored found that congressional parties gain and lose seats based on the battles won and lost by the president.
areas_of_expertise_5: party politics in US and UK

name: Benjamin Lawler
title_3: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
biography: Benjamin Lawler conducts research on improving the efficiency and emissions of internal combustion engines, including the use of alternative fuels or advanced combustion concepts, for example, Low Temperature Combustion (LTC) strategies. His research interests also include drive-cycle modeling and simulation of various vehicle architectures to evaluate the fuel economy benefits of each next-generation technology. This area also includes the modeling and analysis of hybrid vehicles.

name: William E. Lawson
title_1: Professor of Medicine, Director of Cardiac Catheterization Laboratories, Vice Chair of Medicine
biography: William Lawson specializes in cardiovascular disease, coronary artery disease, preventive cardiology, heart failure, interventional cardiology, external counter pulsation, and heart attack. He’s board certified in internal medicine, cardiovascular disease, interventional cardiology, advanced heart failure and transplant cardiology.
